text.value: tell me, in the context of jee app, @Named is the same as @ManagedBean ? when it comes to EJB

In the context of Java EE (Jakarta EE) applications, `@Named` and `@ManagedBean` are not exactly the same, but they serve similar purposes. Here's a brief explanation of each:
1. **`@Named`**: - `@Named` is a Context and Dependency Injection (CDI) annotation introduced in Java EE 6 (Jakarta EE 8). - It is used to define a CDI-managed bean, which can be injected into other components using CDI. - CDI-managed beans are not specific to Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) and can be used in various contexts, such as web applications, EJBs, and even Java SE applications. - CDI-managed beans can have different scopes, such as `@RequestScoped`, `@SessionScoped`, `@ApplicationScoped`, or custom scopes.
2. **`@ManagedBean`**: - `@ManagedBean` is a JavaServer Faces (JSF) annotation introduced in JSF 2.0. - It is used to define a managed bean in the context of JSF applications. - Managed beans are typically used as backing beans for JSF views and can hold data and logic related to the user interface. - Managed beans are managed by the JSF runtime and have a specific lifecycle tied to the JSF request-response cycle. - Managed beans can have different scopes, such as `@RequestScoped`, `@ViewScoped`, `@SessionScoped`, `@ApplicationScoped`, or custom scopes.
In the context of Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB), `@Named` is more commonly used than `@ManagedBean`. EJBs are server-side components that can be injected into other components using CDI. Therefore, `@Named` is the preferred annotation for defining CDI-managed beans that can be used within EJBs or other components that require CDI injection.
However, if you are developing a JSF application that does not involve EJBs, you can use either `@Named` or `@ManagedBean` to define managed beans for the JSF views. In this case, the choice between `@Named` and `@ManagedBean` is primarily a matter of preference and coding style.
It's worth noting that `@Named` is part of the CDI specification, while `@ManagedBean` is specific to JSF. If you plan to use CDI in other contexts beyond JSF, it's generally recommended to use `@Named` for better portability and consistency across different Java EE (Jakarta EE) components.
